69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:38): 20:03 <         69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e> 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: regarding http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2008Nov/0311.html - it would be helpful if you could define what you mean by  "language", since different people mean different things, and it's not clear what you mean

0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (14:38): Title: Re: Should we Publish a Language Specification? from 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 Reschke on 2008-11-19 (<email/> from November 2008) (at lists.w3.org)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:38): the 1 billion USD was a very rough estimate of the cost of one particular attribute that was proposed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:38): it's not a general cost per attribute
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:38): some attributes cost much more, some much less
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:39): ah, so what kind of attributes would be cheaper?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:39): for instance, what is the estimated cost of a/@ping?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:40): with respect to your question: language as in "SGML/XML vocabulary for markup of documents, as opposed to web applications"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:40): who knows, how do you measure the $ revenue of helping a user understand a privacy issue?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:40): also, what is the estimated cost of *removing* attributes?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:41): these are all things to consider on a case by case basis
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:41): generally i wouldn't recommend putting $ values on spec changes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:41): it's rarely helpful
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:41): and the numbers are so widely arbitrary that they're not really comparable

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:43): so w.r.t. to your statement about wanting the definition of the language in a different document than the definition of "the rest", you want the form submission algorithm to be in a different document than the form controls?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:45): Potentially, yes. I haven't thought about that yet.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:45): And yes, I realize that different people want different things.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:47): ok well once http splits the header names into a different spec than the caching algorithm, let me know :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:47): this is definitely not the kind of innovation that i want to be spearheading
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:47): it's a very novel way of writing specs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:47): that no other successful w3c spec that i know of has done
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:47): (or ietf spec for that matter)
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:48): the caching *is* in a different spec
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:48): header names are defined where they belong to (there are different kinds of headers)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:49): RFC 2616 has section 13 and section 14 in the same spec.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:49): which i believe it should, but that's not what you're asking for for html5
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:49): not equivalent to what you're asking for, that is
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:49): I'm not talking about RFC2616, but about what httpbis is doing.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:50): draft-ietf-httpbis-p6-cache-05.txt has section 4 and section 16 in the same spec.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:50): which i believe it should, but that's not equivalent to what you're asking for for html5

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:51): (and as you may be aware, i'm a little concerned about the direction the httpwg is going in in general, so httpbis isn't really what i would use as an example of the way to do things)
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:52): there's no section 16 in part 6

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:52): I hve still not understood the value of trying to split the spec across sections that are heavilly interdependent. However the costs of trying to do so are already obvious
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:52): if your point is that the spec could be split even further: yes, it could.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:52): but there's a balance to keep between too few and too many
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:53): the benefits are:
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:53): different parts can evolve independantly
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:53): part 6 has a section 16 on page 27
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:54): interdependancies become more obvious, so there's more pressure to avoid them
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:55): i have nothing against splitting html5 up, indeed i sent an e-mail asking for editors to do just that
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:55): there is no page 27 in part 6. what are you looking at?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:55): http://www.ietf.org/internet-drafts/draft-ietf-httpbis-p6-cache-05.txt

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:56): but splitting it up as you describe doesn't make sense to me, it's a really novel way of splitting the spec up and i don't understand why we would want to pioneer that in html5, given how much other things we are pioneering here
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:57): is this the wrong part 6? it's the one linked to from http://www.ietf.org/html.charters/httpbis-charter.html
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:57): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: Are those the two principal benefits that you see?
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (14:57): Title: Hypertext Transfer Protocol Bis (httpbis) Charter (at www.ietf.org)
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:57): something is wrong, compare with http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-p5-range-05
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (14:57): Title: draft-ietf-httpbis-p5-range-05 - HTTP/1.1, part 5: Range Requests and Partial Responses (at tools.ietf.org)
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (14:57): will need to figure out what'
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:58): that's part 5

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (14:58): I don't see how splitting parts that have fundamental dependencies on each other will allow either to evolve without the same consideration for the other that they are given today
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:59): http://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-ietf-httpbis-p6-cache-05.txt is the part i am talking about
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:00): sorry, I was confused.

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (15:00): And there are many parts of HTML (in particular the language definition and the processing of the language) that are already irrevesibly cojoined so trying to impose an artificial seperation at this stage has no practical effect on our ability to avoid interdependencies
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:01): so coming back to your question
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:01): httpbis splits into layers. each layer has headers associated with it.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:02): the equivalent would be to have separate HTML specs, for, let's say, scripting or form submission
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:02): of course more granularity would be possible, but as I said before, there needs to be a balance
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:02): the Web platform is split into several specs. Web DOM Core, XMLHttpRequest, HTML5, CSS, JS, etc.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:03): the current size of HTML5 clearly indicates it's out of balance
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:03): viewing HTML5 as a whole, instead of as a part of a whole, is wrong
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:03): hey, html5 is only a little bigger than twice httpbis
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (15:03): in particular because it contains lots of stuff most *authors* of HTML never need to know
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (15:03): sure, we definitely need a view of html5 that hides stuff that doesn't apply to authors
